STATE TREASURER 5 STATE TREASURER'S REPORT December 1, 1916 — November 30, 1918 TREASURY DEPARTMENT, STATE OF NEBRASKA Lincoln, December 1, 1918. To His Excellency, The Governor of Nebraska, and The 37th Session of the Legislature. Sirs: The biennium has been a busy and expensive one — occasioned by the natural growth of the State and the high cost of everything be - cause of the war. The receipts and disbursements for the biennium were the largest in the history of the State. This has been only a natural consequence because the State has been increasing in wealth and business by leaps and bounds, and has kept pace with the progress of the times in education, better properties and improvements, and improved methods in caring for the State's wards. The disbursements of $15,446,849.60 reflect quite an exaggeration of the true expenses of the State government. The Temporary School Fund disbursements are not in any sense an expense of the State government. This is an expense of the local schools of the State. The disbursements from the Permanent School, Permanent University, Agri- KbltAlX^lD The receipts of $15,026,919.41 may be grouped as follows: 1. State Tax Levy $7,365,287.18 2. Lease and Interest on School Lands and Funds, etc 1,866,200.26 3. Bonds and Land Sale contracts paid 2,000,105.61 4. U. S. Government 343,903.22 5. Department Receipts 1,341,218.79 6. University, Normal and Institution Cash 1,947,047.70 7. Transferred 163,156.66 Total $15,026,919.41 DISBURSEMENTS

6 REPORT OF culture College Endowment, Normal Endowment and Bessey Memorial Funds are investments in bonds and are no part of the expenses of the State government. The disbursements may be better understood by the following table of groups: Group No. 1 — (Not State Expenses) Temporary School Apportionments.. ..$1,719,572.02 Trust funds invested 1,993,800.38 Forest Reserve distribution 3,655.87 $3,717,028.27 Group No. 2— (State Expenses) (a) Schools: State University $3,841,767.50 Normal Schools 1,092,964.12 $4,934,731.62 (b) State Government, Institutions and Improvements $6,795,089.71 $11,729,821.33 Total .$151446,849.60 RECEIPTS FROM COUNTY TREASURERS The requirement for monthly remittances from County Treas - urers has been continued thruout the biennium with the same benefits as the previous biennium. The law on the requirement has been de - finitely and plainly set out by the Supreme Court of the State on July 8, 1918 in State v. Ure et al. (Syllabus by the Court) A county treasurer is chargeable with interest on state funds if he fails "to pay the state treasury the amount due the state on his account, for state and other taxes at the time or times required. He must fully state to the auditor the condition of his ac - count with the state upon blanks furnished him by the auditor; and when the auditor has adjusted the account and stated the amount due the state, the account so stated is then "due the state," and he will be chargeable with interest thereon until it is paid to the state treasurer. If the auditor fails to furnish "suitable blanks for the set - tlements of county treasurers with the auditor," as required by section 6520, Rev. St. 1913, or if he refuses to countersign the state treasurer's receipt as required by section 6508, money in the hands of the county treasurer is not "due the state on his account" within the meaning of section 6509. The ruling of the Court stays the requirement of the State Treasurer unless the State Auditor furnishes the necessary blanks to the county treasurers on which to make their monthly settlements,

STATE TREASURER 7 or the county treasurers voluntarily make such remittances. Thus far the most of the county treasurers have voluntarily made monthly re - mittances without the blanks being furnished by the State Auditor. The county treasurers who have not made monthly remittances are not subject to interest penalty because the State Auditor has not furnished such, blanks, and this plan will sooner or later fail unless both the Treasurer and Auditor alike do their duty. I urge my successor to make the requirements of County Treasurers to make monthly re - mitttances, and the incoming Auditor to furnish blanks to the county treasurers on which to make their monthly settlement. The county treasurers may then waive the monthly settlement and make his re - mittance voluntarily, but failing to make such remittance he will be liable to 10 per cent interest to the State on amounts withheld. In order that there may not be any conflict or fall down on this successful business - like method I recommend the passage of a law requiring the county treasurers to make such monthly remittance without a settlement with the Auditor, or a law requiring the Auditor to furnish monthly settle - ment banks. WARRANTS PAID AND CARRIED AS CASH During the previous biennium I paid and carried as cash on hand all warrants on a number of funds in excess of the amount of such funds received. This at times meant the carrying in the Treasury of a large number of warrants, which were paid but not charged off on the books. This caused inconvenience and some hazard when inquiry was made as to whether or not certain warrants had been paid. This inconvenience and hazard has been overcome by charging such warrants against the fund (making an overdraft) and cancelling them on the appropriation bocks as "paid." This explains the new feature of overdraft in the report, which is only a different form of bookkeeping than carrying the warrants as cash. INTEREST ON STATE DEPOSITS According to agreement with the Governor when he vetoed the bill passed by the legislature of 1917 requiring the State Treasurer to deposit the State funds with the banks which offered the highest and best rate of interest on daily balances of such deposits, I adopted such a rule for the inactive depository accounts with the result that the rate of interest has been increased from a uniform 3 per cent to a range of from 3 per cent to 5 per cent. A COMPARISON A comparison of the last three bienniums on School Apportionments, Interest received .on deposits, and interest paid on warrant indebted-

REPORT OF 8 ness will give a slight idea of the benefits to the State on account of monthly remittances by county treasurers and the increase in rate of interest on deposits. POTASH This report we believe should have shown receipts of seveial hundred thousand dollars from potash which could have been produced from the State School lands. The lease holders of these lands were ready and willing to enter competitive bidding for the right to extract these minerals. They 'even urged the leasing, of these rights to the highest and best bidder in order that the State's interest might be fully protected and that they and every other citizen of the State might have a fair opportunity and the equal right of every other to get hold of and develop and produce potash. If this plan of equal right to all and special privileges to none had been followed and put into operation we would have been producing potash by the thousands of tons months ago from State School lands, and the Treasury would have received hundreds of thousands of dollars to the credit of the Temporary School Fund. But when the lease holder became convinced that he was not to have an equal chance with any and all others at getting hold of the privilege of producing potash from the very land on which he already held an agricultural lease, he went into court and knocked the pro - duction of potash from State School lands into a "cocked hat." The incoming legislature should pass a law for the taking pos - session of these valuable minerals by condemnation proceedings, — the paying of proper and adequate damages to present lease holders and then throw potash production open to every body on the competitive bidding (on good faith) plan. STATE TREASURER 9 OFFICE FORCE Individually and as a whole the Office force has maintained its record and reputation for quality and efficient service. Their faithful assisstance and cooperation and council are entitled to full share of credit for the biennium. The records of the Department have been well kept. The personnel of the force is: C. Berge Deputy Ed. Westering Head Book-keeper Edward L. Lewis Second Book-keeper Seymour C. Watson Clerk and Steographer Claude Wilmot Clerk and Stenographer Respectfully Submitted, George E. Hall, State Treasurer.
